Mahindra & Mahindra (M&M) has made significant investments and developed strategies for electric vehicles (EVs) in various segments. Here is an overview of the company's EV plans and strategies:

a. 2W and 3W strategy/plan/investment:
M&M has developed a significant portfolio of electric two-wheelers and three-wheelers. The company's electric scooter range includes the Mahindra Gusto, Mahindra GenZe, and Mahindra Mojo Electric. In the three-wheeler segment, M&M has launched the e-Alfa and e-Alfa Mini electric rickshaws. The company has made significant investments in developing these vehicles and has been expanding its sales and service network for electric two-wheelers and three-wheelers.

b. Passenger vehicle strategy/plan/investment:
M&M has developed and launched electric versions of its popular passenger vehicles. The company's EV portfolio includes the Mahindra eKUV100, Mahindra e-Verito, and Mahindra eXUV300. M&M has invested in developing these vehicles and expanding its charging infrastructure. The company has also been working on developing new EV platforms and technologies to improve the performance and range of its electric passenger vehicles.

c. Commercial vehicle strategy/plan/investment:
M&M has developed electric versions of its commercial vehicles, including the Mahindra eSupro and the Mahindra Treo. The company has been expanding its electric commercial vehicle range and has been working on developing new electric commercial vehicle platforms. M&M has also been investing in charging infrastructure for commercial electric vehicles to support its customers' adoption of EVs.

d. Charging infrastructure strategy/plan/investment (if any):
M&M has been investing in developing its charging infrastructure to support the adoption of electric vehicles. The company has partnered with various companies to set up charging stations across India. M&M has also launched its own charging infrastructure under the "NEMO" brand, which provides customers with easy and convenient access to charging stations.

Overall, M&M's EV plans and strategies demonstrate the company's commitment to developing sustainable and environmentally friendly transportation solutions. The company continues to invest in developing new electric vehicle platforms and expanding its charging infrastructure to support the adoption of EVs in India.

Mahindra and Mahindra (M&M) is one of India's largest multinational corporations, operating in various industries, including automotive, aerospace, and agriculture. In this essay, we will discuss M&M's operations strategy in various aspects.

Inventory Management:
M&M has a well-established inventory management system, which helps the company in maintaining an optimal level of inventory. The company uses various inventory management techniques, such as Just-in-Time (JIT), to reduce inventory carrying costs and improve the efficiency of the supply chain. M&M also uses various IT tools to monitor inventory levels and analyze the demand patterns of different products to avoid stockouts.

Supply Chain Management:
M&M has a robust supply chain management system, which involves sourcing raw materials, manufacturing products, and distributing them to various dealers and distributors. The company has implemented various supply chain management practices, such as vendor management and supplier relationship management, to ensure a steady supply of high-quality raw materials at competitive prices. M&M also uses various IT tools, such as Enterprise Resource Planning (ERP) systems, to manage its supply chain.

Logistics:
M&M has a well-developed logistics system, which involves the transportation of finished goods to dealers and distributors across the country. The company uses various transportation modes, such as road, rail, and sea, to transport its products. M&M also uses various logistics management practices, such as route optimization and fleet management, to improve the efficiency of its logistics system.

Production Management:
M&M has a well-established production management system, which involves the production of various automotive and agricultural products. The company has implemented various production management practices, such as Total Quality Management (TQM), to ensure the quality of its products. M&M also uses various IT tools, such as Computer-Aided Design (CAD) and Computer-Aided Manufacturing (CAM), to improve the efficiency of its production processes.

Policy and Regulation related to outsourcing:
M&M has a policy of outsourcing non-core activities to external vendors to focus on its core competencies. The company follows a rigorous outsourcing process, which involves selecting vendors based on their capabilities and track record. M&M also maintains close relationships with its vendors and provides them with technical and managerial support.

Industrial Processes:
M&M has developed various industrial processes to improve the efficiency and quality of its products. The company has implemented various process improvement techniques, such as Lean manufacturing and Six Sigma, to reduce waste and improve process efficiency. M&M also uses various automation technologies, such as Robotics, to improve the speed and accuracy of its production processes.

Managing Transit Risks:
M&M has a comprehensive risk management system, which involves identifying and mitigating various transit risks, such as theft, damage, and delay. The company uses various risk management techniques, such as insurance and GPS tracking, to minimize the impact of transit risks.

WTO-related aspects:
M&M operates in a global market, and its operations are subject to various international trade regulations, such as the World Trade Organization (WTO) agreements. The company complies with all WTO-related regulations and uses various international trade practices, such as exporting and importing, to expand its business globally.

Overseas payments:
M&M operates in various countries, and its operations involve making overseas payments. The company uses various payment systems, such as wire transfers and online payment gateways, to make overseas payments. M&M also maintains close relationships with its overseas partners and ensures timely payment of invoices.

Kano's model is a technique for analyzing customer needs and identifying what features and characteristics of a product or service are most important to customers. The model divides customer needs into three categories: basic needs, performance needs, and excitement needs.

In the case of Mahindra and Mahindra's product portfolio in India, we can apply Kano's model as follows:

1. Basic needs: Basic needs are essential features that customers expect from a product or service. In the case of Mahindra and Mahindra's products, some basic needs would include reliability, fuel efficiency, safety, and affordability. These are features that are taken for granted and customers may not even mention them when asked about their preferences.
2. Performance needs: Performance needs are features that customers consider when evaluating a product or service. In the case of Mahindra and Mahindra's products, some performance needs would include comfort, handling, acceleration, and towing capacity. These are features that customers expect and consider when making a purchase decision.
3. Excitement needs: Excitement needs are features that go beyond customer expectations and create a unique and memorable experience. In the case of Mahindra and Mahindra's products, some excitement needs would include style, design, and innovative features such as hybrid or electric powertrains. These are features that customers may not expect but would be delighted to see.

By applying Kano's model to Mahindra and Mahindra's product portfolio, the company can identify which features are basic needs, performance needs, and excitement needs for their customers. This can help them prioritize their resources and investments in product development, marketing, and sales.

For example, if Mahindra and Mahindra identifies that safety and reliability are basic needs for their customers, they can ensure that all their products meet these requirements without fail. If they identify that customers are looking for better handling and acceleration, they can focus on improving these performance needs in their new product launches. And if they identify that customers are interested in innovative features such as hybrid or electric powertrains, they can invest in research and development in these areas.

In conclusion, applying Kano's model to Mahindra and Mahindra's product portfolio in India can help the company understand their customers' needs and expectations, and prioritize their operations and strategies accordingly.
